key_points: Aaron Rodgers, Green Bay Packers quarterback, tested positive for COVID-19 and will miss Week 9 game against the Kansas City Chiefs.
Rodgers was placed on the reserve/COVID-19 list; Jordan Love will start in his place.
Despite previous statements of being 'immunized,' Rodgers is not vaccinated against COVID-19.
Rodgers sought an exemption from NFL's COVID-19 protocols based on his antibody levels but was denied.
He underwent homeopathic treatment to raise his antibody levels, which the NFL, NFLPA, and infectious disease consultant did not recognize as valid protection.
Rodgers' non-vaccinated status subjects him to various restrictions, including daily testing and mandatory mask-wearing.
The NFL-NFLPA COVID protocols outline that one could be considered fully vaccinated with one shot, provided specific antibody levels are met.
Sources confirmed that Rodgers has not received any COVID-19 vaccine.
Packers coach Matt LaFleur refrained from commenting on Rodgers' vaccination status, directing questions to Rodgers himself.
Rodgers cannot rejoin the team until Nov. 13, the day before their Week 10 game against the Seahawks.
